The options in Question 15 also cover the same services mentioned in the ground truth MCQ (insect control, pollination, and seed dispersal).

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **15**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever heard the sound of frogs calling at night? For hundreds of millions of years, this croaking lullaby has filled the nighttime air. But recent studies suggest that these frogs are in danger of playing their final note. Over the past few decades, amphibian populations have been rapidly disappearing worldwide. Nearly one-third of the world's amphibian species are endanger of extinction, and over 100 species have already disappeared. But don't worry, there's still hope. Before we get into how to save the frogs, let's start by taking a look at why they're disappearing and why it's important to keep them around. Habitat destruction is the number one problem for frog populations around the world. There are seven billion humans on the planet, and we compete with frogs for habitat. We build cities, suburbs, and farms on top of frog habitat and chop forests and drain the wetlands that serve as home for numerous amphibian populations. Climate change alters precipitation levels, drying up ponds, streams, and cloud forests. As the Earth's human population continues to grow, so will the threats amphibians face. There are a variety of other factors contributing to the frogs' decline. Over-harvesting for the pet and food trade results in millions of frogs being taken out of the wild each year. Invasive species, such as non-native trout and crawfish, eat native frogs. Humans are facilitating the spread of infectious diseases by shipping over 100 million amphibians around the world each year for use as food, pets, bait, and in laboratories and zoos, with few regulations or quarantines. One of these diseases, chytridiomycosis, has driven stream-dwelling amphibian populations to extinction in Africa, Australia, Europe, and North, Central, and South America. On top of all these problems, we add hundreds of millions of kilograms of pesticides to our ecosystems each year. And these chemicals are easily absorbed through amphibians' permeable skin, causing immunosuppression, or a weakened immune system, and developmental deformities. Okay, so why are these little green guys worth keeping around? Frogs are important for a multitude of reasons. They're an integral part of the food web, eating flies, ticks, mosquitoes, and other disease vectors, thus, protecting us against malaria, dengue fever, and other illnesses. Tadpoles keep waterways clean by feeding on algae, reducing the demand on our community's filtration systems and keeping our cost of water low. Frogs serve as a source of food for birds, fish, snakes, dragonflies, and even monkeys. When frogs disappear, the food web is disturbed, and other animals can disappear as well. Amphibians are also extremely important in human medicine. Over ten percent of the Nobel prizes in physiology and medicine have gone to researchers whose work depended on amphibians. Some of the antimicrobial peptides on frog skin can kill HIV, some act as pain killers, and others serve as natural mosquito repellents. Many discoveries await us if we can save the frogs, but when a frog species disappears, so does any promise it holds for improving human health. Fortunately, there are lots of ways you can help, and the best place to start is by improving your ecological footprint and day-to-day actions. The next time you listen to that nighttime lullaby, don't think of it as just another background noise, hear it as a call for help, sung in perfect croaking harmony.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Amphibians are rapidly disappearing around the world and up to ____ of all amphibians are threatened with extinction.
Options: A. 1/10, B. 1/4, C. 1/3, D. 1/2
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: For how long have frogs been calling at night? Options: A. Thousands of years, B. Hundreds of thousands of years, C. Hundreds of millions of years, D. Billions of years Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the primary problem for frog populations worldwide? Options: A. Climate change, B. Over-harvesting for the pet and food trade, C. Habitat destruction, D. Invasive species Correct Option: C
Question 3: What contributes to the complexity of the decline of frog populations? Options: A. A single contributing factor, B. Multiple human activities and natural causes, C. Only human activities, D. Only natural causes Correct Option: B
Question 4: What role do frogs play in maintaining ecosystem balance? Options: A. They only eat disease vectors, B. They only protect humans against illnesses, C. They play a crucial role in maintaining the balance of ecosystems and providing benefits to humans, D. They have no role in maintaining ecosystem balance Correct Option: C
Question 5: What can be done to help mitigate the decline of frog populations in day-to-day actions? Options: A. Increase pesticide use, B. Improve ecological footprint, C. Support the pet and food trade, D. Destroy habitats Correct Option: B
Question 6: What can help protect amphibian populations? Options: A. Reducing pesticide use, conserving habitats, and regulating the pet and food trade, B. Increasing pesticide use, destroying habitats, and supporting the pet and food trade, C. Only reducing pesticide use, D. Only conserving habitats Correct Option: A
Question 7: How does human population growth impact the decline of frog populations? Options: A. It has no impact, B. It has a positive impact on frog populations, C. It increases habitat destruction and resource competition, contributing to the decline of frog populations, D. It only affects frog populations in urban areas Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the impact of climate change on frog populations? Options: A. It has no impact, B. It increases precipitation levels, benefiting frog populations, C. It alters precipitation levels, drying up habitats and negatively impacting frog populations, D. It only affects frog populations in cold climates Correct Option: C
Question 9: What can be developed by combining the understanding of frog population decline with the importance of their role in ecosystems? Options: A. Conservation strategies that prioritize habitat destruction, B. Conservation strategies that prioritize habitat preservation and disease prevention, C. Policies that support the pet and food trade, D. Practices that increase pesticide use Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be fostered by recognizing the interconnectedness of species and ecosystems? Options: A. A holistic approach to conservation, where the preservation of frog species is seen as essential to maintaining ecosystem balance, B. A fragmented approach to conservation, where each species is considered separately, C. A focus on human activities only, D. A disregard for the importance of conservation Correct Option: A
Question 11: What can be used to evaluate the effectiveness of conservation efforts and policies aimed at protecting frog populations? Options: A. Their impact on human health only, B. Their impact on ecosystem balance only, C. Their impact on population decline and ecosystem health, D. Their cost only Correct Option: C
Question 12: What should be considered when evaluating the pet and food trade's impact on amphibian populations? Options: A. The economic benefits only, B. The ethics of the trade and its impact on population decline, C. The importance of preserving frog species, D. The value of conservation efforts Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly present in the provided options. However, based on the content and intent, I would recommend Question 7 as the closest match.

Although Question 7 does not directly ask about the proportion of amphibians threatened with extinction, it does address the impact of human population growth on the decline of frog populations, which is related to the broader context of the ground truth MCQ.

A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that directly asks about the proportion of amphibians threatened with extinction, but such an option is not available in the provided list.

If I had to choose from the available options, I would suggest Question 7 as the closest match, but with the understanding that it's not a perfect match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 7

Question 6: What can help protect amphibian populations?

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever heard the sound of frogs calling at night? For hundreds of millions of years, this croaking lullaby has filled the nighttime air. But recent studies suggest that these frogs are in danger of playing their final note. Over the past few decades, amphibian populations have been rapidly disappearing worldwide. Nearly one-third of the world's amphibian species are endanger of extinction, and over 100 species have already disappeared. But don't worry, there's still hope. Before we get into how to save the frogs, let's start by taking a look at why they're disappearing and why it's important to keep them around. Habitat destruction is the number one problem for frog populations around the world. There are seven billion humans on the planet, and we compete with frogs for habitat. We build cities, suburbs, and farms on top of frog habitat and chop forests and drain the wetlands that serve as home for numerous amphibian populations. Climate change alters precipitation levels, drying up ponds, streams, and cloud forests. As the Earth's human population continues to grow, so will the threats amphibians face. There are a variety of other factors contributing to the frogs' decline. Over-harvesting for the pet and food trade results in millions of frogs being taken out of the wild each year. Invasive species, such as non-native trout and crawfish, eat native frogs. Humans are facilitating the spread of infectious diseases by shipping over 100 million amphibians around the world each year for use as food, pets, bait, and in laboratories and zoos, with few regulations or quarantines. One of these diseases, chytridiomycosis, has driven stream-dwelling amphibian populations to extinction in Africa, Australia, Europe, and North, Central, and South America. On top of all these problems, we add hundreds of millions of kilograms of pesticides to our ecosystems each year. And these chemicals are easily absorbed through amphibians' permeable skin, causing immunosuppression, or a weakened immune system, and developmental deformities. Okay, so why are these little green guys worth keeping around? Frogs are important for a multitude of reasons. They're an integral part of the food web, eating flies, ticks, mosquitoes, and other disease vectors, thus, protecting us against malaria, dengue fever, and other illnesses. Tadpoles keep waterways clean by feeding on algae, reducing the demand on our community's filtration systems and keeping our cost of water low. Frogs serve as a source of food for birds, fish, snakes, dragonflies, and even monkeys. When frogs disappear, the food web is disturbed, and other animals can disappear as well. Amphibians are also extremely important in human medicine. Over ten percent of the Nobel prizes in physiology and medicine have gone to researchers whose work depended on amphibians. Some of the antimicrobial peptides on frog skin can kill HIV, some act as pain killers, and others serve as natural mosquito repellents. Many discoveries await us if we can save the frogs, but when a frog species disappears, so does any promise it holds for improving human health. Fortunately, there are lots of ways you can help, and the best place to start is by improving your ecological footprint and day-to-day actions. The next time you listen to that nighttime lullaby, don't think of it as just another background noise, hear it as a call for help, sung in perfect croaking harmony.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A simple way to help frogs is to _____.
Options: A. Improving your ecological footprint, B. Living a more environmentally-friendly life, C. Not using pesticides, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: For how long have frogs been calling at night? Options: A. Thousands of years, B. Hundreds of thousands of years, C. Hundreds of millions of years, D. Billions of years Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the primary problem for frog populations worldwide? Options: A. Climate change, B. Over-harvesting for the pet and food trade, C. Habitat destruction, D. Invasive species Correct Option: C
Question 3: What contributes to the complexity of the decline of frog populations? Options: A. A single contributing factor, B. Multiple human activities and natural causes, C. Only human activities, D. Only natural causes Correct Option: B
Question 4: What role do frogs play in maintaining ecosystem balance? Options: A. They only eat disease vectors, B. They only protect humans against illnesses, C. They play a crucial role in maintaining the balance of ecosystems and providing benefits to humans, D. They have no role in maintaining ecosystem balance Correct Option: C
Question 5: What can be done to help mitigate the decline of frog populations in day-to-day actions? Options: A. Increase pesticide use, B. Improve ecological footprint, C. Support the pet and food trade, D. Destroy habitats Correct Option: B
Question 6: What can help protect amphibian populations? Options: A. Reducing pesticide use, conserving habitats, and regulating the pet and food trade, B. Increasing pesticide use, destroying habitats, and supporting the pet and food trade, C. Only reducing pesticide use, D. Only conserving habitats Correct Option: A
Question 7: How does human population growth impact the decline of frog populations? Options: A. It has no impact, B. It has a positive impact on frog populations, C. It increases habitat destruction and resource competition, contributing to the decline of frog populations, D. It only affects frog populations in urban areas Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the impact of climate change on frog populations? Options: A. It has no impact, B. It increases precipitation levels, benefiting frog populations, C. It alters precipitation levels, drying up habitats and negatively impacting frog populations, D. It only affects frog populations in cold climates Correct Option: C
Question 9: What can be developed by combining the understanding of frog population decline with the importance of their role in ecosystems? Options: A. Conservation strategies that prioritize habitat destruction, B. Conservation strategies that prioritize habitat preservation and disease prevention, C. Policies that support the pet and food trade, D. Practices that increase pesticide use Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be fostered by recognizing the interconnectedness of species and ecosystems? Options: A. A holistic approach to conservation, where the preservation of frog species is seen as essential to maintaining ecosystem balance, B. A fragmented approach to conservation, where each species is considered separately, C. A focus on human activities only, D. A disregard for the importance of conservation Correct Option: A
Question 11: What can be used to evaluate the effectiveness of conservation efforts and policies aimed at protecting frog populations? Options: A. Their impact on human health only, B. Their impact on ecosystem balance only, C. Their impact on population decline and ecosystem health, D. Their cost only Correct Option: C
Question 12: What should be considered when evaluating the pet and food trade's impact on amphibian populations? Options: A. The economic benefits only, B. The ethics of the trade and its impact on population decline, C. The importance of preserving frog species, D. The value of conservation efforts Correct Option: B

natural enemies the good bugs instead of wearing special clothes and gas masks and applied chemicals so safety with respect to the application this is number one answer that we get from growers why biological control number two many growers are in fact petrified from the idea of resistance that the pests will become resistant to the chemicals just in our case that bacteria become resistant to antibiotics it's the same and it can happen very quickly fortunately in the biological control or in the natural control resistance is extremely rare it hardly happens because this is evolution this is the natural issue unlike resistance which happens in the case of chemicals and thirdly public demand public demand the more the public the public demands reduction of chemicals more growers become aware of the fact they should wherever they can and wherever possible replace the chemical control with biological control even here there is another grower you see very interested in the bugs the bad ones and the good ones wearing this magnifier already on her head just walking safely in her crop finally i want to get to actually to my vision or in fact my dream because you see this is the reality have a look at the gap if we take the overall turnover of the biocontrol industry worldwide is 250 million dollars and look at the overall pesticide industry in all the crops throughout the world i think it's times 100 or something like that 25 billion so there is a huge gap to bridge so actually how can we do it how can we bridge or let's say never disgrace this gap in the course of the years first of all we need to find more robust good and reliable biological solutions more good bugs that we can either mass produce or actually conserve in the field secondly to create even more intensive and strict public demand to reduction of chemicals in the agriculture of fresh produce and thirdly also to increase awareness by the growers to the potential of this industry and this gap really narrows step by step it does never so i think my last slide is all we are saying we can actually see it give nature a chance so i'm saying it on behalf of all the biocontrol practitioners and implementers in israel and abroad really give nature a chance thank you

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What exactly is biological pest control?
Options: A. "Good" bugs eating "bad" bugs
Correct Option: A

Question 4: What is the benefit of using natural enemies in biological pest control? Options: A. They can be used to pollinate crops, B. They can be used to fertilize crops, C. They can be used to control pest populations, D. They can be used to monitor pest populations Correct Option: C

Question 10: What could help to bridge the gap between the current use of biological pest control and its potential? Options: A. plot by reducing those chemicals that's the whole idea and what is the impact in this table you can actually see what is an impact of a successful biological control by good bugs for example in israel where we employ more than one thousand hectares ten thousand donuts in israeli terms of biological pest-controlling sweet pepper under protection seventy-five percent of the pesticides were actually reduced and the israelis strawberries even more 80 percent of the pesticide especially those aimed against pest mites in strawberries so the impact is very strong and there goes the question especially if you ask growers agriculturalists why biological control why good bugs by the way the number of answers you get equals to the number of people you ask but if we go for example to this place southeast israel the arava valley along the great rift valley where the really top-notch the pearl of the israeli agriculture is located especially under greenhouse conditions or under screen house conditions if you drive all the way to a lot you see this just in the middle of the desert and if you zoom in you can definitely watch this grandparents with their grandchildren distribute the natural enemies the good bugs instead of wearing special clothes and gas masks and applied chemicals so safety with respect to the application this is number one answer that we get from growers why biological control number two many growers are in fact petrified from the idea of resistance that the pests will become resistant to the chemicals just in our case that bacteria become resistant to antibiotics it's the same and it can happen very quickly fortunately in the biological control or in the natural control resistance is extremely rare it hardly happens because this is evolution this is the natural issue unlike resistance which happens in the case of chemicals and thirdly public demand public demand the more the public the public demands reduction of chemicals more growers become aware of the fact they should wherever they can and wherever possible replace the chemical control with biological control even here there is another grower you see very interested in the bugs the bad ones and the good ones wearing this magnifier already on her head just walking safely in her crop finally i want to get to actually to my vision or in fact my dream because you see this is the reality have a look at the gap if we take the overall turnover of the biocontrol industry worldwide is 250 million dollars and look at the overall pesticide industry in all the crops throughout the world i think it's times 100 or something like that 25 billion so there is a huge gap to bridge so actually how can we do it how can we bridge or let's say never disgrace this gap in the course of the years first of all we need to find more robust good and reliable biological solutions more good bugs that we can either mass produce or actually conserve in the field secondly to create even more intensive and strict public demand to reduction of chemicals in the agriculture of fresh produce and thirdly also to increase awareness by the growers to the potential of this industry and this gap really narrows step by step it does never so i think my last slide is all we are saying we can actually see it give nature a chance so i'm saying it on behalf of all the biocontrol practitioners and implementers in israel and abroad really give nature a chance thank you

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does Shimon say that biological pest-control will help to achieve?
Options: A. Help to reduce the amount of chemical pesticides, B. Control the amount of bugs in the world, C. Help stronger and bigger bugs live longer, D. Help weaker and smaller bugs die out faster
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What did the speaker major in at Tel Aviv University? Options: A. Entomology, B. Zoology, C. Biology, D. Environmental Science Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the estimated number of predatory mites produced per gram at the facility in Kibbutz Deliao? Options: A. 40,000, B. 60,000, C. 80,000, D. 100,000 Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the primary goal of biological pest control? Options: A. To increase crop yields, B. To reduce the use of chemicals in plant protection, C. To eliminate all pests from agricultural settings, D. To promote integrated pest management (IPM) Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the benefit of using natural enemies in biological pest control? Options: A. They can be used to pollinate crops, B. They can be used to fertilize crops, C. They can be used to control pest populations, D. They can be used to monitor pest populations Correct Option: C
Question 5: In which of the following settings can biological pest control be applied? Options: A. Only in greenhouses, B. Only in fields, C. In both greenhouses and fields, D. In neither greenhouses nor fields Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is an example of a crop that can benefit from biological pest control using natural enemies? Options: A. Corn, B. Wheat, C. Strawberries, D. Soybeans Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the speaker, what is a rare occurrence when using biological pest control? Options: A. Resistance to biological control, B. Resistance to chemicals, C. The development of new pests, D. The increase in crop yields Correct Option: A
Question 8: What does the speaker identify as a gap in the current use of biological pest control? Options: A. The lack of public demand for biological pest control, B. The lack of government policies supporting biological pest control, C. The gap between the current use of biological pest control and its potential, D. The lack of funding for research on biological pest control Correct Option: C
Question 9: According to the speaker, what could lead to more effective and sustainable pest management? Options: A. Combining biological pest control with other methods, such as IPM, B. Using only biological pest control, C. Using only chemical pest control, D. Eliminating all pests from agricultural settings Correct Option: A
Question 10: What could help to bridge the gap between the current use of biological pest control and its potential? Options: A. Increasing awareness among growers and the public about the benefits of biological pest control, B. Decreasing funding for research on biological pest control, C. Reducing the use of chemicals in plant protection, D. Eliminating all pests from agricultural settings Correct Option: A
Question 11: According to the speaker, what is a benefit of using biological pest control compared to chemical pest control? Options: A. Biological pest control is more expensive, B. Biological pest control is less effective, C. Biological pest control is more sustainable and environmentally friendly, D. Biological pest control is more time-consuming Correct Option: C
Question 12: What could drive the adoption of biological pest control, according to the speaker? Options: A. Public demand and government policies that support sustainable agriculture, B. The lack of funding for research on biological pest control, C. The lack of public awareness about the benefits of biological pest control, D. The use of chemical pest control Correct Option: A

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long have we been knowingly using biological pest control?
Options: A. The last 500 years, B. The last 50 years, C. The last 10 years, D. The last 120 years
Correct Option: D

think it's times 100 or something like that 25 billion so there is a huge gap to bridge so actually how can we do it how can we bridge or let's say never disgrace this gap in the course of the years first of all we need to find more robust good and reliable biological solutions more good bugs that we can either mass produce or actually conserve in the field secondly to create even more intensive and strict public demand to reduction of chemicals in the agriculture of fresh produce and thirdly also to increase awareness by the growers to the potential of this industry and this gap really narrows step by step it does never so i think my last slide is all we are saying we can actually see it give nature a chance so i'm saying it on behalf of all the biocontrol practitioners and implementers in israel and abroad really give nature a chance thank you

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What exactly are they doing at Shimon's research lab?
Options: A. Create chemicals the mimic the actions of predatory bugs, B. Research how to completely eliminate both predatory and problem bugs, C. Naturally mass produce the natural enemies to problem bugs, D. Experiment on how to create new bugs that will eliminate the need for pest control
Correct Option: C

Question: How many acres of land can one gram of predatory bug mites protect?
Options: A. One acre of land, B. Half an acre of land, C. 45 acres of land, D. Less than 1/3 of an acres of land
Correct Option: A

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the gap between the turnover of the biological pest control industry and the chemical pest control industry?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the gap between the turnover of the biological pest control industry and the chemical pest control industry?
Options: A. 250 Million to 2.5 Billion, B. 250,000 to 2.5 Million, C. 100,000 to 250 Million, D. 250 Million to 2.5 Billion
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary cause of global warming? Options: A. Deforestation and land degradation, B. Burning fossil fuels and releasing greenhouse gases, C. Industrial pollution and waste management, D. Overpopulation and consumption patterns Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following gases is a significant contributor to the greenhouse effect? Options: A. Oxygen (O2), B. Nitrogen (N2), C. Methane (CH4), D. Carbon dioxide (CO2) Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the main difference between climate change and global warming? Options: A. Climate change refers to natural temperature fluctuations, while global warming refers to human-induced temperature increases., B. Climate change refers to human-induced temperature increases, while global warming refers to natural temperature fluctuations., C. Climate change encompasses both natural and human-induced temperature changes, while global warming specifically refers to human-induced temperature increases., D. Climate change and global warming are interchangeable terms. Correct Option: C
Question 4: How does climate change affect sea levels? Options: A. Climate change causes sea levels to decrease due to increased evaporation., B. Climate change causes sea levels to remain constant., C. Climate change causes sea levels to fluctuate randomly., D. Climate change causes sea levels to rise due to melting glaciers, ice sheets, and thermal expansion. Correct Option: D
Question 5: A company wants to reduce its carbon footprint. Which of the following options would be the most effective way to achieve this goal? Options: A. Installing energy-efficient lighting and HVAC systems, B. Purchasing carbon credits and offsets, C. Installing solar panels on the company's roof, D. Investing in renewable energy infrastructure, such as wind farms or solar panels Correct Option: D
Question 6: A community is experiencing frequent flooding due to rising sea levels. Which of the following adaptation strategies would be most effective in addressing this issue? Options: A. Implementing a flood warning system and emergency preparedness plan, B. Relocating residents to higher ground or elevated areas, C. Increasing flood insurance coverage and financial support, D. Implementing a combination of flood-control measures, including building seawalls, restoring natural barriers, and upgrading drainage systems Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the relationship between climate change and extreme weather events? Options: A. Climate change directly causes extreme weather events., B. Extreme weather events directly cause climate change., C. Climate change and extreme weather events are unrelated., D. Climate change exacerbates and increases the likelihood of extreme weather events. Correct Option: D
Question 8: Which of the following factors contributes to the unequal distribution of climate change impacts across different regions? Options: A. Latitude and geographical location, B. Altitude and elevation, C. Socioeconomic factors, including poverty, inequality, and access to resources, D. Population density and urbanization Correct Option: C
Question 9: How can climate change mitigation efforts be integrated into urban planning policies? Options: A. By increasing green spaces and urban forestry, B. By promoting public transportation and non-motorized transportation, C. By investing in renewable energy sources and energy-efficient infrastructure, D. By implementing a comprehensive approach that includes energy-efficient building codes, waste reduction programs, climate-resilient infrastructure, and green transportation options Correct Option: D
Question 10: What role can international cooperation play in addressing the global impacts of climate change? Options: A. By establishing a global carbon pricing system and emissions trading, B. By promoting the sharing of climate change research, technologies, and best practices, C. By providing financial support, capacity building, and technology transfer to vulnerable countries, D. By coordinating global climate governance, diplomacy, and cooperation to address the global impacts of climate change Correct Option: D
Question 11: What are the ethical implications of climate change on future generations? Options: A. Climate change has no significant ethical implications for future generations., B. Climate change has significant ethical implications for future generations, including impacts on their human rights, quality of life, and environmental heritage., C. Climate change has moderate ethical implications for future generations, primarily related to economic opportunities and resource availability., D. Climate change has minimal ethical implications for future generations, limited to environmental concerns. Correct Option: B
Question 12: How can the effectiveness of climate change policies be evaluated? Options: A. By measuring the reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and mitigation outcomes, B. By assessing the economic impacts, costs, and benefits of climate change policies, C. By evaluating the social and environmental co-benefits, including public health and ecosystem services, D. By using a combination of metrics, including greenhouse gas emissions reduction, economic impacts, social and environmental co-benefits, and policy implementation effectiveness Correct Option: D

Question 3: What is the main difference between climate change and global warming? Options: A. Climate change refers to natural temperature fluctuations, while global warming refers to human-induced temperature increases., B. Climate change refers to human-induced temperature increases, while global warming refers to natural temperature fluctuations., C. Climate change encompasses both natural and human-induced temperature changes, while global warming specifically refers to human-induced temperature increases., D. Climate change and global warming are interchangeable terms. Correct Option: C
Question 4: How does climate change affect sea levels? Options: A. Climate change causes sea levels to decrease due to increased evaporation., B. Climate change causes sea levels to remain constant., C. Climate change causes sea levels to fluctuate randomly., D. Climate change causes sea levels to rise due to melting glaciers, ice sheets, and thermal expansion. Correct Option: D

Climate change has moderate ethical implications for future generations, primarily related to economic opportunities and resource availability., D. Question 3: What is the primary difference between the social layer and the game layer, according to Seth Priebatsch? Options: A. The social layer is about influence, while the game layer is about connections., B. The social layer is about connections, while the game layer is about influence., C. The social layer is about technology, while the game layer is about behavior., D. The social layer is about behavior, while the game layer is about technology. Correct Option: B

The game layer should be designed for entertainment purposes only., C. The game layer should be designed in a way that is open, available, and can be leveraged for positive outcomes., D. Question 7: What is the relationship between the social layer and the game layer, according to Seth Priebatsch? Options: A. The game layer is built on top of the social layer and influences behavior., B. The social layer is built on top of the game layer and influences behavior., C. The game layer and social layer are separate entities with no relationship., D. The game layer is a replacement for the social layer. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is Seth Priebatsch's critique of existing games and systems that use game dynamics? Options: A. They are too focused on entertainment and not enough on education., B. They are too focused on personal gain and not enough on positive outcomes., C. They are poorly designed and do not effectively influence behavior., D. They are not using game dynamics consciously. Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is an example of combining game dynamics to create a new and innovative game or system, as mentioned by Seth Priebatsch? Options: A. Creating a game that only uses the Appointment Dynamic, B. Designing a system that incorporates both the Progression Dynamic and Communal Discovery, C. Developing a mobile app that only uses the Influence and Status dynamic, D. Building a website that only uses the Appointment Dynamic Correct Option: B

The game layer will have a positive impact on society., C. The game layer will have both positive and negative impacts on society., D. The game layer will have no impact on society. Question 2: According to Seth Priebatsch, what will be the focus of the next decade? Options: A. Social media, B. Games and game dynamics, C. Technology and innovation, D. Virtual reality Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary difference between the social layer and the game layer, according to Seth Priebatsch? Options: A. The social layer is about influence, while the game layer is about connections., B. The social layer is about connections, while the game layer is about influence., C. The social layer is about technology, while the game layer is about behavior., D. The social layer is about behavior, while the game layer is about technology. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is Seth Priebatsch's emphasis regarding the game layer and its potential impact on society? Options: A. The game layer should be designed for personal gain., B. The game layer should be designed for entertainment purposes only., C. The game layer should be designed in a way that is open, available, and can be leveraged for positive outcomes., D. The game layer should be designed to manipulate people's behavior. Correct Option: C
Question 5: Which of the following is an example of applying game dynamics to influence behavior in a real-world context, as mentioned by Seth Priebatsch? Options: A. Creating a social media platform for entertainment purposes, B. Designing a game to increase engagement in education, C. Using the Appointment Dynamic to encourage people to take their medicine on time, D. Building a website for e-commerce Correct Option: C
Question 6: Which game dynamic is most relevant to a marketing campaign that aims to increase customer loyalty, according to Seth Priebatsch? Options: A. Appointment Dynamic, B. Influence and Status, C. Progression Dynamic, D. Communal Discovery Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between the social layer and the game layer, according to Seth Priebatsch? Options: A. The game layer is built on top of the social layer and influences behavior., B. The social layer is built on top of the game layer and influences behavior., C. The game layer and social layer are separate entities with no relationship., D. The game layer is a replacement for the social layer. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is Seth Priebatsch's critique of existing games and systems that use game dynamics? Options: A. They are too focused on entertainment and not enough on education., B. They are too focused on personal gain and not enough on positive outcomes., C. They are poorly designed and do not effectively influence behavior., D. They are not using game dynamics consciously. Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is an example of combining game dynamics to create a new and innovative game or system, as mentioned by Seth Priebatsch? Options: A. Creating a game that only uses the Appointment Dynamic, B. Designing a system that incorporates both the Progression Dynamic and Communal Discovery, C. Developing a mobile app that only uses the Influence and Status dynamic, D. Building a website that only uses the Appointment Dynamic Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is Seth Priebatsch's assessment of the potential impact of the game layer on society? Options: A. The game layer will have a negative impact on society., B. The game layer will have a positive impact on society., C. The game layer will have both positive and negative impacts on society., D. The game layer will have no impact on society. Correct Option: C

player spend something like six six and a half hours a day on it they most their most dedicated players it's like a full-time job it's it's insane and they have these systems where you can level up um and that's a very powerful thing progression is powerful uh it can also be used in very compelling ways for good uh one of the things that we work on at scavenger is how do you use games to drive traffic and drive business to local businesses to sort of something that is very key to the economy and here we have a game you know that people play they go places they do challenges they earn points and we've introduced a progression Dynamic into it where by going to the same place over and over by doing challenges by engaging with the business you move a green bar from the left edge of the screen to the right edge of the screen and you eventually unlock rewards um and this is powerful enough that we can see that it hooks people into these Dynamics pulls them back to the same local businesses creates huge loyalty creates engagement and is able to drive meaningful revenue and fun and engagement to businesses uh these progression Dynamics are powerful and can be used in the real world uh the final one I want to talk about and it's a great one to end on is this concept of communal Discovery a dynamic in which everyone has to work together to achieve something uh and communal Discovery is powerful because it leverages the network that is society to solve problems um this is used in some sort of famous consumer web stories like dig which I'm sure you've all heard of uh dig is a communal Dynamic to try and find and Source the best news the most interesting stories and they made this into a game uh initially they had a leaderboard where if you recommended the best stories you would get points uh and that that really motivated people to find the best stories but it became so powerful that there was actually a cabal a group of people the top seven uh on the leaderboard who would work together to make sure that they maintained that position and they would recommend other people's stories and the game became more powerful than the goal and they actually had to end up shutting down the leaderboard because while it was effective it was so powerful that it stopped sourcing the best stories and started having people work to maintain their leadership so we have to use this one carefully um it's also used in things like McDonald's Monopoly where the game is not the Monopoly game you're playing but these sort of cottage industries that form to try and find Boardwalk right and now they're just looking for a little sticker that says Boardwalk but it can also be used to find real things uh this is the DARPA balloon challenge where they hid a couple balloons all across the United States and said use networks try and find these balloons fastest and the winner will get $40,000 and the winner was actually a group out of MIT where they created sort of a pyramid scheme a network where the first person to recommend the location of a balloon got $2,000 and anyone else to you know push that recommendation up also got a cut of it and in 12 hours they were able to find all these balloons all across the country right really powerful Dynamic and so I've got about you know 20 seconds so if I'm going to leave you with anything uh last decade was the decade of social this next decade is the decade of games we use game Dynamics to build on it we build with mind share we can influence behavior it is very powerful it is very exciting let's all build it together let's do it well and have fun [Applause] playing

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the definition that Seth gives for the "communal discovery" gaming dynamic?
Options: A. A dynamic that requires people to share their finances, B. A dynamic that requires everyone to know each other very well, C. A dynamic where everyone must have one certain role in the process, D. A dynamic where everyone has to work together to achieve something
Correct Option: D

Question 1: What is Seth Priebatsch's title at SCVNGR? Options: A. CEO, B. Chief Ninja, C. Founder, D. President Correct Option: B

Question 3: What is the primary difference between the social layer and the game layer, according to Seth Priebatsch? Options: A. The social layer is about influence, while the game layer is about connections., B. The social layer is about connections, while the game layer is about influence., C. The social layer is about technology, while the game layer is about behavior., D. The social layer is about behavior, while the game layer is about technology. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is Seth Priebatsch's emphasis regarding the game layer and its potential impact on society? Options: A. The game layer should be designed for personal gain., B. The game layer should be designed for entertainment purposes only., C. The game layer should be designed in a way that is open, available, and can be leveraged for positive outcomes., D. The game layer should be designed to manipulate people's behavior. Correct Option: C
Question 5: Which of the following is an example of applying game dynamics to influence behavior in a real-world context, as mentioned by Seth Priebatsch? Options: A. Creating a social media platform for entertainment purposes, B. Designing a game to increase engagement in education, C. Using the Appointment Dynamic to encourage people to take their medicine on time, D. Building a website for e-commerce Correct Option: C
Question 6: Which game dynamic is most relevant to a marketing campaign that aims to increase customer loyalty, according to Seth Priebatsch? Options: A. Appointment Dynamic, B. Influence and Status, C. Progression Dynamic, D. Communal Discovery Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between the social layer and the game layer, according to Seth Priebatsch? Options: A. The game layer is built on top of the social layer and influences behavior., B. The social layer is built on top of the game layer and influences behavior., C. The game layer and social layer are separate entities with no relationship., D. The game layer is a replacement for the social layer. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is Seth Priebatsch's critique of existing games and systems that use game dynamics? Options: A. They are too focused on entertainment and not enough on education., B. They are too focused on personal gain and not enough on positive outcomes., C. They are poorly designed and do not effectively influence behavior., D. They are not using game dynamics consciously. Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is an example of combining game dynamics to create a new and innovative game or system, as mentioned by Seth Priebatsch? Options: A. Creating a game that only uses the Appointment Dynamic, B. Designing a system that incorporates both the Progression Dynamic and Communal Discovery, C. Developing a mobile app that only uses the Influence and Status dynamic, D. Building a website that only uses the Appointment Dynamic Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is Seth Priebatsch's assessment of the potential impact of the game layer on society? Options: A. The game layer will have a negative impact on society., B. The game layer will have a positive impact on society., C. The game layer will have both positive and negative impacts on society., D. The game layer will have no impact on society. Correct Option: C

convinced that you share the central passion of my life a passion for the live professional performing arts performing arts that represent the orchestral repertoire yes but jazz as well modern dance opera theatre and more and more and more you know frankly it's a sector that many of us who work in the field worry is being endangered and possibly dismantled by technology while we initially in the morning or 8:00 at night ordering jeans tailor-made for our unique body types ex expectations of personalization and customization that the live performing arts which have set curtain times set venues attended inconveniences of travel parking and the like simply cannot meet and we're all acutely aware what's it gonna mean in the future when we asked someone to pay $100 for a symphony opera or ballet ticket when that cultural consumer is used to downloading on the Internet 24 hours a day for 99 cents a song or for free these are enormous questions for those of us that work in this terrain but as particular as they feel to us we know we're not alone all of us are engaged in a seismic fundamental realignment of culture and communications a realignment that is shaking and decimating the newspaper industry the magazine industry the book and publishing industry and more saddled in the Performing Arts as we are by antiquated union agreements that inhibit and often prohibit mechanical reproduction in streaming locked into large facilities that were designed to ossify the ideal relationship between artist and audience most appropriate to the 19th century and is pure invention the maps they gave us are out-of-date by years and for those of you who love the arts aren't you glad you invited me here to brighten your day now rather than saying that we're a bit brink of our own annihilation I prefer to believe that we are engaged in a fundamental Reformation a Reformation like the religious Reformation of the 16th century the arts Reformation like the religious Reformation is spurred in part by technology with indeed the printing press really leading the charge on the religious and Reformation both Reformation czar predicated on fractious discussion internal self-doubt and massive realignment of antiquated business models and at heart both Reformation I think we're asking the questions who's entitled to practice how are they entitled to practice and indeed do we need anyone to inter mediate for us in order to have an experience with a spiritual divine Chris Anderson someone I trust you all know editor-in-chief of Wired magazine and author of the long tale really was the first for me to nail a lot of this he wrote a long time ago you know thanks to the invention of the internet web cell a web technology minicams and more the means of artistic production have been democratized for the first time in all of human history in the 1930s if any of you wanted to make a movie you had to work for Warner Brothers or RKO because who could afford a movie set and lighting equipment and editing equipment and scoring and more and now who in this room doesn't know a 14-year old hard at work on her second third or fourth movie similarly the means of artistic distribution have been democratized for the first time in human history again in the 30s Warner Brothers RKO did that for you now go to youtube facebook you have worldwide distribution without leaving the privacy of your own bedroom this double impact is occasioning a massive redefinition of the cultural market a time when anyone is a potential author frankly what we're seeing now in this environment is a massive time when the entire world is changing as we move from a time when audience numbers are plummeting but the number of arts participants people who write poetry who sing songs who perform in church choirs is exploding beyond our wildest imaginations this group others have called the pro Am's amateur artists doing work at a professional level you see them on YouTube and dance competitions film festivals and more they are radically expanding our notions of the potential of an aesthetic vocabulary while they are challenging and undermining the cultural autonomy of our traditional institutions ultimately we now live in a world defined not by consumption but by participation but I want to be clear just as the religious Reformation did not spell the end to the formal church or to the priesthood I believe that our artistic institutions will continue to have importance they currently are the best opportunities for artists to have lives of economic dignity not opulence of dignity and they are the places where artists who deserve and want to work at a certain scale of resources will find a home but to view them as synonymous with the entirety of the arts community as by far too short-sighted and indeed while we've tended to polarize the amateur from the professional the single most exciting development in the last five to ten years has been the rise of the professional hybrid artist the professional artist who works not primarily in the concert hall or on the stage but most frequently around women's rights or human rights around global warming issues or AIDS relief or more not out of economic necessity but out of a deep organic conviction that the work that she or he is called to do cannot be accomplished in the traditional hermetic arts environment today's dance world is not defined solely by the Royal Winnipeg Ballet or the National Ballet of Canada but by Liz Lerman's dance exchange a multi-generational professional dance company whose dancers range in age from 18 to 82 and who work with genomic scientists to embody the DNA strand and with nuclear physicists at CERN today's professional theater community is defined not only by the Shah and Stratford festivals but by the cornerstone Theatre of Los Angeles a collective of artists that after nine Levin brought together ten different religious communities the Baha'i the Catholic the Muslim the Jewish even the Native American and the gay and lesbian communities of faith helping them create their own individual plays and one massive play where they explored the differences in their faith and found commonality as an important first step toward cross community healing today's performers like we're deaf salons work in women's prisons helping women prisoners articulate the pain of incarceration while today's playwrights and directors work with youth gangs do you find alternate channels to violence and more and more and more and indeed I think rather than being annihilated the Performing Arts are poised on the brink of a time where we will be more important than we have ever been you know we've said for a long time we are critical to the health of the economic communities in your town and absolutely I hope you know that every dollar spent on a performing arts ticket in a community generates five to seven additional dollars for the local economy dollars spent in restaurants from parking at the fabric stores where we buy fabric for costumes the piano tuner who chooses the instruments and more but the arts are going to be more important to economies as we go forward especially in industries we can't even imagine yet just as they have been central to the iPod and the computer game industries which few if any of us could have foreseen 10 to 15 years ago business leadership will depend more and more on emotional intelligence the ability to listen deeply to have empathy to articulate change to motivate others the very capacities that the arts cultivate with every encounter especially now as we all must confront the fallacy of a market only orientation uninformed by social conscience we must seize and celebrate the power of the Arts to shape our individual and national characters and especially characters of the young people who all too often are subjected to bombardment of sensation rather than digested experience ultimately especially now in this world where we live in a context of regressive and onerous immigration laws in reality-tv that thrives on humiliation and in its context of announcements where the thing we hear most repeatedly day-in day-out in the United States in every train station every bus station every plane station is ladies and gentlemen please report any suspicious behavior or suspicious individuals to the authorities nearest you when all of these ways we are encouraged to view our fellow human being with hostility and fear and contempt and suspicion the arts whatever they do whenever they call us together invite us to look at our fellow human being with generosity and curiosity god knows if we have ever needed that capacity in human history we need it now you know we're bound together not I think by Technology Entertainment Design but by common cause we work to promote healthy vibrant societies to ameliorate human suffering to promote a more thoughtful subjective empathic World Order I salute all of you as activists in that quest and urge you to embrace and hold dear the arts in your work whatever your purpose may be I promise you the hand of the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation is stretched out in friendship for now and years to come and I thank you for your kindness and your patience and listening to me this afternoon thank you and Godspeed

and celebrate the power of the Arts to shape our individual and national characters and especially characters of the young people who all too often are subjected to bombardment of sensation rather than digested experience ultimately especially now in this world where we live in a context of regressive and onerous immigration laws in reality-tv that thrives on humiliation and in its context of announcements where the thing we hear most repeatedly day-in day-out in the United States in every train station every bus station every plane station is ladies and gentlemen please report any suspicious behavior or suspicious individuals to the authorities nearest you when all of these ways we are encouraged to view our fellow human being with hostility and fear and contempt and suspicion the arts whatever they do whenever they call us together invite us to look at our fellow human being with generosity and curiosity god knows if we have ever needed that capacity in human history we need it now you know we're bound together not I think by Technology Entertainment Design but by common cause we work to promote healthy vibrant societies to ameliorate human suffering to promote a more thoughtful subjective empathic World Order I salute all of you as activists in that quest and urge you to embrace and hold dear the arts in your work whatever your purpose may be I promise you the hand of the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation is stretched out in friendship for now and years to come and I thank you for your kindness and your patience and listening to me this afternoon thank you and Godspeed

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many hours will a typical entering college student have spent online in total?
Options: A. 10,000 hours, B. 5,000 hours, C. 100,000 hours, D. 20,000 hours
Correct Option: D

convinced that you share the central passion of my life a passion for the live professional performing arts performing arts that represent the orchestral repertoire yes but jazz as well modern dance opera theatre and more and more and more you know frankly it's a sector that many of us who work in the field worry is being endangered and possibly dismantled by technology while we initially prohibit mechanical reproduction in streaming locked into large facilities that were designed to ossify the ideal relationship between artist and audience most appropriate to the 19th century and religious Reformation is spurred in part by technology with indeed the printing press really leading the charge on the religious and Reformation both Reformation czar predicated on fractious discussion internal self-doubt and massive realignment of antiquated business models and at heart both Reformation I think we're asking the questions who's entitled to practice how are they entitled to practice and indeed do we need anyone to inter mediate for us in order to have an experience with a spiritual divine Chris Anderson someone I trust you all know editor-in-chief of Wired magazine could afford a movie set and lighting equipment and editing equipment and scoring and more and now who in this room doesn't know a 14-year old hard at work on her second third or fourth movie worldwide distribution without leaving the privacy of your own bedroom this double impact is occasioning a massive redefinition of the cultural market a time when anyone is a potential author frankly write poetry who sing songs who perform in church choirs is exploding beyond our wildest imaginations this group others have called the pro Am's amateur artists doing work at a professional level you see them on YouTube and dance competitions film festivals and more they are radically expanding our notions of the potential of an aesthetic vocabulary while they are challenging and undermining the cultural autonomy of our traditional institutions ultimately we now live in a world defined not by consumption but by participation but I want to be clear just as the religious Reformation did not spell the end to the formal church or to the priesthood I believe that our artistic institutions will continue to have importance they currently are the best opportunities for artists to have lives of economic dignity not opulence of dignity and they are the places where artists who deserve and want to work at a certain scale of resources will find a home but to view them as synonymous with the entirety of the arts community as by far too short-sighted and indeed while we've tended to polarize the amateur from the professional the single most exciting development in the last five to ten years has been the rise of the professional hybrid artist the professional artist who works not primarily in the concert hall or on the stage but most frequently around women's rights or human rights around global warming issues or AIDS relief or more not out of economic necessity but out of a deep organic conviction that the work that she or he is called to do cannot be accomplished in the traditional hermetic arts environment today's dance world is not defined solely by the Royal Winnipeg Ballet or the National Ballet of Canada but by Liz Lerman's dance exchange a multi-generational professional dance company whose dancers range in age from 18 to 82 and who work with genomic scientists to embody the DNA strand and with nuclear physicists at CERN today's professional theater community is defined not only by the Shah and Stratford festivals but by the cornerstone Theatre of Los Angeles a collective of artists that after nine Levin brought together ten different religious communities the Baha'i the Catholic the Muslim the Jewish even the Native American and the gay and lesbian communities of faith helping them create their own individual plays and one massive play where they explored the differences in their faith and found commonality as an important first step toward cross community healing today's performers like we're deaf salons work in women's prisons helping women prisoners articulate the pain of incarceration while today's playwrights and directors work with youth gangs do you find alternate channels to violence and more and more and more and indeed I think rather than being annihilated the Performing Arts are poised on the brink of a time where we will be more important than we have ever been you know we've said for a long time we are critical to the health of the economic communities in your town and absolutely I hope you know that every dollar spent on a performing arts ticket in a community generates five to seven additional dollars for the local economy dollars spent in restaurants from parking at the fabric stores where we buy fabric for costumes the piano tuner who chooses the instruments and more but the arts are going to be more important to economies as we go forward especially in industries we can't even imagine yet just as they have been central to the iPod and the computer game industries which few if any of us could have foreseen 10 to 15 years ago business leadership will depend more and more on emotional intelligence the ability to listen deeply to have empathy to articulate change to motivate others the very capacities that the arts cultivate with every encounter especially now as we all must confront the fallacy of a market only orientation uninformed by social conscience we must seize and celebrate the power of the Arts to shape our individual and national characters and especially characters of the young people who all too often are subjected to bombardment of sensation rather than digested experience ultimately especially now in this world where we live in a context of regressive and onerous immigration laws in reality-tv that thrives on humiliation and in its context of announcements where the thing we hear most repeatedly day-in day-out in the United States in every train station every bus station every plane station is ladies and gentlemen please report any **Ground Truth MCQ**:

**Transcript**:
I am a cultural omnivore one whose daily commute is made possible by attachment to an iPod an iPod that contains vogner and Mozart pop diva Christina Aguilera country singer Josh Turner got gangster rap artist Kirk Franklin concerto symphonies and more and more I'm a voracious reader a reader who do deals with Ian McEwan down to Stephenie Meyer I have read the Twilight tetralogy and one who lives for my home theater a home theater write of our DVDs video-on-demand and for a lot of television for me Law & Order SVU Tina Fey and 30 rock and Judge Judy the people are real the cases are real the rulings are final now I'm convinced a lot of you probably share my passions especially my passion for Judge Judy and you fight anybody who attempted to take her away from us but I'm a little less convinced that you share the central passion of my life a passion for the live professional performing arts performing arts that represent the orchestral repertoire yes but jazz as well modern dance opera theatre and more and more and more you know frankly it's a sector that many of us who work in the field worry is being endangered and possibly dismantled by technology while we initially heralded the internet as the fantastic new marketing device that was going to solve all our problems we now realize that the Internet is if anything too effective in that regard depending on who you read an arts organization or an artist who tries to attract the attention of a potential single ticket buyer now competes with between three and five thousand different marketing messages a typical citizen sees every single day we now know in fact that technology's our biggest competitor for leisure time five years ago Gen Xers spent 20.7 hours online and TV the majority on TV Gen Y are spent even more twenty three point eight hours the majority online and now a typical in a typical university entering student arrives at college already having spent twenty thousand hours online and an additional ten thousand hours playing video games a stark reminder that we operate in a cultural context where video games now outsell music and movie recordings combined moreover we're afraid that technology has altered our very assumptions of cultural consumption thanks to the internet we believe we can get anything we want whenever we want it delivered to our own doorstep we can shop at 3:00 in the morning or 8:00 at night ordering jeans tailor-made for our unique body types ex expectations of personalization and customization that the live performing arts which have set curtain times set venues attended inconveniences of travel parking and the like simply cannot meet and we're all acutely aware what's it gonna mean in the future when we asked someone to pay $100 for a symphony opera or ballet ticket when that cultural consumer is used to downloading on the Internet 24 hours a day for 99 cents a song or for free these are enormous questions for those of us that work in this terrain but as particular as they feel to us we know we're not alone all of us are engaged in a seismic fundamental realignment of culture and communications a realignment that is shaking and decimating the newspaper industry the magazine industry the book and publishing industry and more saddled in the Performing Arts as we are by antiquated union agreements that inhibit and often prohibit mechanical reproduction in streaming locked into large facilities that were designed to ossify the ideal relationship between artist and audience most appropriate to the 19th century and locked into a business model dependent on high ticket revenues where we charge exorbitant prices many of us shudder in the wake of the collapse of Tower Records and ask ourselves are we next everyone I talked to in performing arts resonates to the world of aid words of Adrian rich who in dreams of a common language wrote we are out in a country that has no language no laws whatever we do together is pure invention the maps they gave us are out-of-date by years and for those of you who love the arts aren't you glad you invited me here to brighten your day now rather than saying that we're a bit brink of our own annihilation I prefer to believe that we are engaged in a fundamental Reformation a Reformation like the religious Reformation of the 16th century the arts Reformation like the religious Reformation is spurred in part by technology with indeed the printing press really leading the charge on the religious and Reformation both Reformation czar predicated on fractious discussion internal self-doubt and massive realignment of antiquated business models and at heart both Reformation I think we're asking the questions who's entitled to practice how are they entitled to practice and indeed do we need anyone to inter mediate for us in order to have an experience with a spiritual divine Chris Anderson someone I trust you all know editor-in-chief of Wired magazine and author of the long tale really was the first for me to nail a lot of this he wrote a long time ago you know thanks to the invention of the internet web cell a web technology minicams and more the means of artistic production have been democratized for the first time in all of human history in the 1930s if any of you wanted to make a movie you had to work for Warner Brothers or RKO because who could afford a movie set and lighting equipment and editing equipment and scoring and more and now who in this room doesn't know a 14-year old hard at work on her second third or fourth movie similarly the means of artistic distribution have been democratized for the first time in human history again in the 30s Warner Brothers RKO did that for you now go to youtube facebook you have worldwide distribution without leaving the privacy of your own bedroom this double impact is occasioning a massive redefinition of the cultural market a time when anyone is a potential author frankly what we're seeing now in this environment is a massive time when the entire world is changing as we move from a time when audience numbers are plummeting but the number of arts participants people who write poetry who sing songs who perform in church choirs is exploding beyond our wildest imaginations this group others have called the pro Am's amateur artists doing work at a professional level you see them on YouTube and dance competitions film festivals and more they are radically expanding our notions of the potential of an aesthetic vocabulary while they are challenging and undermining the cultural autonomy of our traditional institutions ultimately we now live in a world defined not by consumption but by participation but I want to be clear just as the religious Reformation did not spell the end to the formal church or to the priesthood I believe that our artistic institutions will continue to have importance they currently are the best opportunities for artists to have lives of economic dignity not opulence of dignity and they are the places where artists who deserve and want to work at a certain scale of resources will find a home but to view them as synonymous with the entirety of the arts community as by far too short-sighted and indeed while we've tended to polarize the amateur from the professional the single most exciting development in the last five to ten years has been the rise of the professional hybrid artist the professional artist who works not primarily in the concert hall or on the stage but most frequently around women's rights or human rights around global warming issues or AIDS relief or more not out of economic necessity but out of a deep organic conviction that the work that she or he is called to do cannot be accomplished in the traditional hermetic arts environment today's dance world is not defined solely by the Royal Winnipeg Ballet or the National Ballet of Canada but by Liz Lerman's dance exchange a multi-generational professional dance company whose dancers range in age from 18 to 82 and who work with genomic scientists to embody the DNA strand and with nuclear physicists at CERN today's professional theater community is defined not only by the Shah and Stratford festivals but by the cornerstone Theatre of Los Angeles a collective of artists that after nine Levin brought together ten different religious communities the Baha'i the Catholic the Muslim the Jewish even the Native American and the gay and lesbian communities of faith helping them create their own individual plays and one massive play where they explored the differences in their faith and found commonality as an important first step toward cross community healing today's performers like we're deaf salons work in women's prisons helping women prisoners articulate the pain of incarceration while today's playwrights and directors work with youth gangs do you find alternate channels to violence and more and more and more and indeed I think rather than being annihilated the Performing Arts are poised on the brink of a time where we will be more important than we have ever been you know we've said for a long time we are critical to the health of the economic communities in your town and absolutely I hope you know that every dollar spent on a performing arts ticket in a community generates five to seven additional dollars for the local economy dollars spent in restaurants from parking at the fabric stores where we buy fabric for costumes the piano tuner who chooses the instruments and more but the arts are going to be more important to economies as we go forward especially in industries we can't even imagine yet just as they have been central to the iPod and the computer game industries which few if any of us could have foreseen 10 to 15 years ago business leadership will depend more and more on emotional intelligence the ability to listen deeply to have empathy to articulate change to motivate others the very capacities that the arts cultivate with every encounter especially now as we all must confront the fallacy of a market only orientation uninformed by social conscience we must seize and celebrate the power of the Arts to shape our individual and national characters and especially characters of the young people who all too often are subjected to bombardment of sensation rather than digested experience ultimately especially now in this world where we live in a context of regressive and onerous immigration laws in reality-tv that thrives on humiliation and in its context of announcements where the thing we hear most repeatedly day-in day-out in the United States in every train station every bus station every plane station is ladies and gentlemen please report any suspicious behavior or suspicious individuals to the authorities nearest you when all of these ways we are encouraged to view our fellow human being with hostility and fear and contempt and suspicion the arts whatever they do whenever they call us together invite us to look at our fellow human being with generosity and curiosity god knows if we have ever needed that capacity in human history we need it now you know we're bound together not I think by Technology Entertainment Design but by common cause we work to promote healthy vibrant societies to ameliorate human suffering to promote a more thoughtful subjective empathic World Order I salute all of you as activists in that quest and urge you to embrace and hold dear the arts in your work whatever your purpose may be I promise you the hand of the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation is stretched out in friendship for now and years to come and I thank you for your kindness and your patience and listening to me this afternoon thank you and Godspeed

Options: A. Call us together to consider one another with generosity and curiosity, B. Make us a more capitalistic society, C. Encourage us to tune each other out to listen to our iPods, D. Ask us to donate more money
Correct Option: A
